comments.content: It's not Zapf, it's really close, and you were right about the Linotype angle: it's [Robert Slimbach](http://web.archive.org/web/20081208063813/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/itc-slimbach/).

Huh.   
Is it just me, or does it seem that Robert Slimbach has lost \*something\* on the way to the -admittedly generally nice- place he is now?   
   
hhp
Now _that_ was a bit obscure for us non-native English speakers. I can't make head nor tales from what you just wrote. What're you getting at, Hrant?

To me ITC Slimbach seems to have a certain free spirit that Slimbach's contemporary work lacks (according to more people than me). Don't get me wrong, in most ways his stuff is much better now.   
   
hhp

I must confess I'm not particularly a fan of Slimbach's, and I don't know what he's been up to these past few years. Last thing I know of is his exquisite interpretation of [Jenson](http://web.archive.org/web/20081208063813/http:/www.adobe.com/type/browser/P/P_1715.jhtml?id=type-010) from 1996.   
   
I just checked Adobe's site. So he did [Warnock](http://web.archive.org/web/20081208063813/http:/www.adobe.com/type/browser/P/P_1709.jhtml?id=type-010) and that [Today Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20081208063813/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/today-sans/) [rip-off](http://web.archive.org/web/20081208063813/http:/www.adobe.com/type/browser/P/P_1733.jhtml?id=type-010), some scripts... What else have I been missing out? Most of his work is a bit too slick for my taste though. That's always been my main problem with Zapf too.   
   
Remember Picasso, who even in his early realistic paintings added a jarring element because "perfection is boring".

Warnock is actually not bad, although it still has some of that trademark sterility deep down. As for Zapf, I don't think he's as "slick". Perfection: the nice thing about it is that it doesn't exist. Problems become manifest when you try too hard to reach it.   
   
hhp

Wise words indeed, hhp. (But I've still got a problem with some of [Zapf's](http://web.archive.org/web/20081208063813/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/zapf-book-ef/) [trademark](http://web.archive.org/web/20081208063813/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/zapf-international/) [curves](http://web.archive.org/web/20081208063813/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/zapf-international/)).
